Introduction

Minimal change disease (MCD) is a type of nephrotic syndrome caused by glomerular podocyte dysfunction.  MCD is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (~90% of cases), but it can also develop in adults (~10% of cases of nephrotic syndrome in adults).

Pathophysiology



The pathogenesis of MCD likely begins with dysregulation of T-cell subpopulations.  Dysfunctional T cells cause an overproduction of glomerular permeability factor (eg, IL-13) that damages the capillary wall of the glomerulus, leading to cytokine-mediated disruption of the actin cytoskeleton within podocytes, resulting in podocyte injury and effacement (

figure 1
).  Podocyte effacement causes a loss of charge selectivity across the glomerular basement membrane, resulting in the selective loss of urinary anions (particularly albumin) and leading to massive proteinuria.  The resulting hypoalbuminemia leads to decreased plasma oncotic pressure with renal sodium retention, resulting in acute-onset, gravity-dependent edema (eg, periorbital, scrotal, tibial).

Risk factors



The primary risk factor for MCD is age, because MCD accounts for up to 90% of the causes of nephrotic syndrome in children age 1-10.  MCD can also be induced by other causes (ie, secondary MCD), including drugs (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), malignancies (eg, Hodgkin lymphoma), and autoimmune disorders.

Clinical presentation



Patients present with acute symptoms of nephrotic syndrome (

figure 2
):



  • Nephrotic range proteinuria (>3.5 g/day in adults, >50 mg/kg/day in children), often with foamy-appearing urine
  • Hypoalbuminemia (<3.0 g/dL)
  • Gravity-dependent, peripheral edema


Patients typically first develop edema in the periorbital region, followed by the genitals and lower extremities.  The edema may progress to generalized anasarca with ascites, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion.  Other clinical manifestations may include hyperlipidemia (due to liver synthesis of lipoproteins in response to decreased oncotic pressure) and thromboembolism (due to loss of coagulation factors).

Diagnostic evaluation



When any nephrotic syndrome is suspected, it is confirmed by both of the following tests:



  • Nephrotic range proteinuria with a 24-hour urine protein collection:  >3.5 g/day in adults and >50 mg/kg/day in children (or early morning protein-to-creatinine ratio >2)
  • Hypoalbuminemia:  plasma albumin level <3.0 g/dL


Although the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is MCD, other potential causes of nephrotic syndrome (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus) should be excluded.  These tests include:



  • Urinalysis with microscopy
  • Complete blood count
  • Serum electrolyte levels
  • Serum BUN and creatinine levels
  • Serum electrolyte levels


Most patients with MCD have relatively normal laboratory testing; abnormal testing (eg, low serum complement levels, red cell casts on urine microscopy) are concerning for another etiology of the patient's nephrotic syndrome and should be further evaluated.



The diagnosis of MCD in pediatric populations is usually clinical and does not require biopsy or imaging in patients with classic findings.  However, renal biopsy is indicated in pediatric patients with atypical presentations (eg, hypertension, hematuria, elevated creatinine) or treatment-resistant disease.  In addition, all adults with nephrotic syndrome undergo biopsy due to increased likelihood of etiologies other than MCD (eg, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis).



If renal biopsy is performed, the characteristic microscopy findings of MCD include:



  • Light microscopy that shows normal findings
  • Immunofluorescence staining that shows no immunoglobulin or complement deposits
  • Electron microscopy that shows podocyte effacement (diagnostic of MCD) (
    image 1
    )

Management



Because primary MCD is likely immune-mediated, initial treatment is with corticosteroids.  During treatment, urine protein levels are monitored to evaluate for treatment response and disease remission, which are defined as resolution of proteinuria and normalization of serum albumin concentration.  The vast majority of patients respond to steroid therapy and achieve remission within several weeks to months.



A small percentage of patients do not respond to corticosteroid therapy.  In these cases, patients may need further evaluation (eg, kidney biopsy) and/or change in treatment to a steroid-sparing, immunosuppressive agent (eg, mycophenolate mofetil, calcineurin inhibitor [eg, tacrolimus]).

Prognosis



The most important prognostic factor in MCD is the initial response to corticosteroids.  Corticosteroids are very effective in achieving remission; however, many patients with MCD will have at least one relapse, and some children will relapse frequently (several times in a year).  Therefore, once initial remission is achieved, monitoring for proteinuria is required for early identification of relapse.  Relapses typically remain steroid responsive; most children eventually have a progressive decrease in the number of relapses with age and often achieve permanent remission.  Renal outcome is excellent with maintenance of normal renal function into adulthood.

Summary



Minimal change disease (
